sections.content: Inheritance and Variation are key biological processes that explain how traits and characteristics are transferred from one generation to the next and why differences occur among individuals.
Genetics is the branch of biology that deals with the study of heredity and variation.

sections.meaning: The transmission of genetic characters from parents to offspring.
Differences in characteristics among individuals of the same species or between generations.

sections.content: Heredity ensures continuity of traits, while variation ensures individuality among organisms.
Mendel’s Experiments
Gregor Johann Mendel, known as the Father of Genetics, performed experiments on pea plants (Pisum sativum) to understand how traits are inherited from parents to offspring.

sections.title: Reasons for Selecting Pea Plant
items: Pea plants have distinct and contrasting traits.
They can self-pollinate and cross-pollinate easily.
They have a short life cycle and produce many offspring.

sections.content: Mendel’s Laws of Inheritance

sections.title: Three Laws Proposed by Mendel
items: Law of Dominance
Law of Segregation
Law of Independent Assortment

sections.meaning: When two alleles are combined, one allele (dominant) expresses itself while the other (recessive) remains hidden.
Allele pairs separate during gamete formation, and each gamete carries only one allele for each gene.
Genes for different traits assort independently during gamete formation.

sections.content: Mendel used dihybrid crosses to prove the law of independent assortment.
Important Genetic Terms

sections.title: Key Genetic Terms
rows: A unit of inheritance controlling a specific character.
Alternative forms of a gene located on homologous chromosomes.
Having identical alleles for a trait (e.g., TT or tt).
Having two different alleles for a trait (e.g., Tt).
The genetic makeup of an organism.
The observable physical appearance of an organism.

sections.content: Punnett Square is a graphical representation used to predict the genotype and phenotype ratios of offspring in crosses.
Monohybrid Cross
A cross between two organisms considering a single pair of contrasting traits. Example: Tall (TT) × Dwarf (tt).

sections.title: Results of Monohybrid Cross
items: F1 Generation – All tall (Tt).
F2 Generation – 3 Tall : 1 Dwarf (Phenotypic ratio).
Genotypic ratio – 1 TT : 2 Tt : 1 tt.

sections.content: Dihybrid Cross
A cross between two organisms considering two pairs of contrasting traits. Example: Round Yellow (RRYY) × Wrinkled Green (rryy).

sections.title: Results of Dihybrid Cross
items: F1 Generation – All Round Yellow (RrYy).
F2 Generation – 9 Round Yellow : 3 Round Green : 3 Wrinkled Yellow : 1 Wrinkled Green.

sections.content: Phenotypic ratio of dihybrid cross is 9:3:3:1.
Deviations from Mendelian Inheritance

sections.title: Non-Mendelian Patterns
items: Incomplete Dominance – Neither allele completely dominates (e.g., Snapdragon flower colour).
Codominance – Both alleles express equally (e.g., ABO blood group).
Multiple Alleles – A gene with more than two allelic forms (e.g., I gene for blood group).
Polygenic Inheritance – Multiple genes control a single trait (e.g., skin colour in humans).

sections.content: Chromosomal Theory of Inheritance

sections.meaning: Proposed by Sutton and Boveri. It states that genes are located on chromosomes and their segregation during meiosis explains inheritance.

sections.content: Mendel’s factors (genes) are located on chromosomes, hence gene behaviour and chromosomal movement are interrelated.
Linkage and Recombination

sections.meaning: The tendency of genes located close together on a chromosome to be inherited together.
Formation of new gene combinations due to crossing over during meiosis.

sections.content: Sex Determination
Sex determination is the process by which an organism’s sex is established. It is controlled by specific sex chromosomes.

sections.title: Different Mechanisms of Sex Determination
rows: Male has only one X chromosome.

sections.content: Mutation and Genetic Disorders

sections.meaning: A sudden heritable change in the DNA sequence of an organism that may lead to alteration in phenotype.

sections.title: Types of Genetic Disorders
items: Chromosomal disorders – caused by changes in chromosome number or structure (e.g., Down’s syndrome, Turner’s syndrome).
Mendelian disorders – caused by mutation in a single gene (e.g., Sickle-cell anaemia, Haemophilia).

sections.content: Genetic counselling is useful to detect and manage hereditary diseases early.
Summary

items: Mendel’s experiments laid the foundation of genetics.
Inheritance follows predictable patterns controlled by genes and alleles.
Chromosomes carry genes that determine traits.
Deviations like incomplete dominance, codominance, and polygenic inheritance exist.
Sex is determined by specific sex chromosomes.
Mutations and genetic disorders lead to variations and diseases.
